sentence: My fridge exploded. . . and there are pieces of de-brie everywhere.
explanation: debris refers to scattered fragments and de-brie plays on the act of removing (debris) clothing, suggesting a humorous interpretation of a situation
first_new_sentence: The builders had to clear the de-brie after the storm caused significant damage to their worksite.
second_new_sentence: After the meal, he decided to de-brie himself of his formal attire to relax at home.

sentence: What do you call a cow with no nipples? yomama #getrekt
explanation: nipples refers to the small projections on a mammals body and plays on the words reference to something that can be absent
first_new_sentence: The infant calf needs its mothers nipples to nurse and grow strong.
second_new_sentence: The scientist examined a different kind of plant that produces non-nipples as part of its reproductive process.

sentence: A boy walks up to his teacher with a broken pencil... this has no point.
explanation: point refers both to the tip of the pencil and the idea of a meaningful argument or statement
first_new_sentence: The teacher highlighted the importance of each point in the discussion to help students understand the topic.
second_new_sentence: After sharpening his pencil, he realized the point was still too dull to write properly.

sentence: Note: The above extraction only includes jokes with single words that meet the specified conditions. Some jokes were excluded as they didnt comply with the definition of a word with dual meanings in one context without involving homophones or compound words.
